thematic in rmarkdown

Carson Sievert

2020-06-04

Source: vignettes/rmarkdown.Rmd
rmarkdown.Rmd

thematic_on() works everywhere in rmarkdown so long as you specify the colors and fonts (rendering Google Fonts may require some additional setup, though). When it comes to auto detection, there are 3 situations where it can work:

  1. A runtime: shiny document where plots are generated via renderPlot() (or renderImage).
  2. An output format that builds on html_document_base() with a non-NULL theme.
  3. Other output formats that call auto_config_set() for you.

Auto detection in html_document

Auto detection of colors and fonts is (partially) supported for output formats that build on html_document_base() with a non-NULL theme, for example:

---
output: 
  html_document:
    theme: darkly
---

```{r setup, include=FALSE}
library(thematic)
thematic_on()
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = FALSE)
```

## {.tabset .tabset-pills}

### ggplot

```{r}
library(ggplot2)
ggplot(mtcars, aes(wt, mpg, label = rownames(mtcars), color = factor(cyl))) +
        geom_point() +
        ggrepel::geom_text_repel()
```

### lattice

```{r}
lattice::show.settings()
```

### base

```{r}
image(volcano, col = thematic_get_option("sequential"))
```

Partial support in this case means that auto detection doesn’t support custom CSS, but it will detect equivalent styling performed via bootstraplib. For example, auto detection wouldn’t be able to pick up on custom CSS like this in your document:

<style> 
  body{font-family: Pacifico} 
</style>

However, if you instead style the document via bootstraplib code inside the document, then auto detection can pick up on that custom styling (see here for more info on styling via bootstraplib):

bootstraplib::bs_theme_fonts("Pacifico")

Rendering Google Fonts

Rendering Google Fonts in rmarkdown requires either showtext or ragg to be installed. showtext works with rmarkdown’s default graphics devices, so make sure it’s installed to render Google Fonts on those devices in rmarkdown. If, for some reason, rendering fails, you might need to also make sure the fig.showtext option is set to TRUE.

# install.packages("showtext")
knitr::opts_chunk$set(fig.showtext = TRUE)

thematic will do this for you when it’s loaded (i.e., on library(thematic)), but that also means you can’t start using showtext until the next code chunk.

To use ragg’s png device instead, which in some environments (especially hosted ones) can produce higher quality and consistent output in less time (see here for more details), do the following in a setup code chunk:

# install.packages("ragg")
knitr::opts_chunk$set(dev = "ragg_png")

Note that dev = "ragg_png" requires knitr v1.29 or higher (if you can’t use that recent of a version you can also set the device yourself)

Auto detection in other output formats

Auto detecting in other output formats can in theory work if the output format sets auto_config_set().
